texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My first full-time job was purely technical. Most of my interview centered around my abilities to manage and maintain Linux servers since the company had very limited Linux knowledge. Once I was hired, my main responsibility was maintaining a single Red Hat Linux 9 server.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Yes. A single server. And no, not Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9. Red Hat Linux 9. (It was 2005.)
texts.text: Yes. A single server. And no, not Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9. Red Hat Linux 9. (It was 2005.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I spent the first three months of that job focused on learning as much as I could about everything that was running on that Linux server. My success was directly tied to my ability to keep it running.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've mentored several technical people over the years and these common themes show up often:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My ideas never seem to get any attention in meetings.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Nobody ever reviews my pull requests.

texts.label: paragraph

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's entirely possible that you're performing terribly in your role and writing awful code, but I doubt it. Much of this comes down to how you communicate in your daily work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the book  Switch: How to change things when change is hard , the authors talk about the concept of a rider and an elephant. (Please read the book because I can't do it justice here. It's a great read.)
texts.text: In the book  Switch: How to change things when change is hard , the authors talk about the concept of a rider and an elephant. (Please read the book because I can't do it justice here. It's a great read.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Elephants are very large, very stubborn, and very strong. The rider could certainly make small adjustments in the elephant's path, but if the elephant want to make a hard left turn, the rider is along for the ride.
texts.text: Elephants are very large, very stubborn, and very strong. The rider could certainly make small adjustments in the elephant's path, but if the elephant want to make a hard left turn, the rider is along for the ride.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The elephant is a metaphor for our emotions. They have a huge impact on how we act and they're very difficult to change. Emotions usually don't match up with reason at all.
texts.text: The elephant is a metaphor for our emotions. They have a huge impact on how we act and they're very difficult to change. Emotions usually don't match up with reason at all.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The rider is a metaphor for reason and analytical thinking. Reason and data can only do so much with our emotions are in control.

texts.orig: The secret is to make the problem  real  for your coworkers and appeal to their emotions. (For a lot more detail here, see my post on  Persuasion Engineering .) This means you must tell a story with a beginning, middle, and end from a  very  important perspective. For most companies, the customer perspective is paramount.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: How do I work on my soft skills?
texts.text: How do I work on my soft skills?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: An easy first step is to look back at recent interactions that didn't go as you expected. Try to put yourself in the other person's shoes and come up with reasons why they rejected your change.
texts.text: An easy first step is to look back at recent interactions that didn't go as you expected. Try to put yourself in the other person's shoes and come up with reasons why they rejected your change.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Were they confused about the goal? Was it difficult to see how it affected the customer? Did you explain the why?
texts.text: Were they confused about the goal? Was it difficult to see how it affected the customer? Did you explain the why?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A mentor (formal or informal) can help here, too. Find someone you trust and get candid feedback from them about your performance. Trust is key, because without it, you won't get the feedback you're looking for. Make sure you ask about  specific  aspects of your performance, such as a particular meeting or pull request.
